title: Question 43

children: A 51-year-old woman is hospitalized for fever, confusion, tremors, involuntary movements of her arms and legs, and lower extremity weakness. Her illness began with fever, malaise and headache quickly followed by neurologic symptoms. She was airlifted from China back to the United States. She has spent the last 3 months working in rural and urban areas of Nepal, South Korea, Vietnam, and China. Her only travel-related precautions have been daily atovaquone-proguanil to prevent malaria. Medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no other medications.

On physical examination, she is confused. Temperature is 38.8 °C (101.8 °F); other vital signs are normal. Nuchal rigidity is noted. Choreoathetoid movements are observed. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
MRI of the brain with contrast shows abnormalities in the basal ganglia and thalamus.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Symptomatic Japanese encephalitis typically manifests as a nonspecific febrile, viral-like illness quickly followed by an encephalopathic state.
). Infection follows the bite of the

group of mosquitoes and is rarely symptomatic, but in patients who do develop clinical illness, the initial presentation is a nonspecific, febrile, viral-like illness with headache. Neurologic manifestations develop rapidly, encephalitis being the most common. Focal neurologic abnormalities, including paresis, cranial nerve palsies, flaccid paralysis, and parkinsonian-like movement disorders, frequently accompany the encephalopathic state. Some patients become comatose. Japanese encephalitis may also present as mild, febrile, aseptic meningitis. Thalamic lesions seen on MRI scans are typical; diagnosis is confirmed by early detection of IgM antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid, and later in the serum. Although the virus is endemic throughout most of Asia and portions of the Western Pacific, the incidence of infection is low in travelers to these areas. A vaccine is available that can produce effective immunity.

). Humans acquire the disease through the bite of the larval stage of mites known as chiggers. It is predominantly present in Asia, although infection can also occur in parts of Europe, Africa, and South America. A black eschar is often present at the site of inoculation; this is followed by fever, rash, and various multiorgan system symptoms. Central nervous system complications are infrequent.
) is a flavivirus infection spread by members of the

species of ticks, which, along with rodents, function as viral reservoirs. Characteristically, clinical infection manifests in a biphasic manner, beginning with a febrile viral-like illness, a brief period of defervescence, and one or more neurologic syndromes. The lack of a biphasic illness makes tick-borne encephalitis unlikely in this patient.
mosquitoes spread the yellow fever virus (

) to humans, either from nonhuman primates (jungle or sylvatic yellow fever) or by person-to-person spread (urban yellow fever). Fever, headache, myalgia, nausea, and vomiting are common symptoms in those who become symptomatic, some of whom may progress to severe multisystem disease manifested by jaundice, kidney injury, and hemorrhagic shock.

references: Pavli A, Maltezou HC. Travel-acquired Japanese encephalitis and vaccination considerations. J Infect Dev Ctries. 2015;9(9):917–924.
